Comment: >"ICE was carrying out a court authorized search warrant for a large-scale human smuggling investigation. The case has been accepted for federal prosecution in the Northern District of Oklahoma,” a senior DHS official told *The Independent*. "The search warrants included the location of an address where U.S. citizens recently moved. The previous residents were the intended targets. The investigation resulted in the indictment of eight Guatemalan nationals for their roles in smuggling illegal aliens into the United States. Two of the eight indicted aliens have criminal convictions for narcotics possession, identity fraud, money laundering, and re-entry after deportation."  Nothing in this statement addresses the reason they decided to traumatize an innocent family without checking first that they had the right people. And nothing in this statement explains why they decided to **steal the money and possessions of innocent people and not give them back!** Wtf!! Stealing is normally illegal, but in this case, it's okay? (I understand that if someone's accused of a crime, evidence needs to be collected. But in this case, it was discovered that the family was innocent, so what's the excuse?)

Comment: That’s the fun part of civil asset forfeiture. You don’t even have to be guilty to have “suspicious” property seized because the property’s “suspiciousness” is all the justification needed.  “Why, if not for illegal purposes, would you have $10k in cash?” “I don’t trust banks and am going to buy a used car in cash.” “Hmmm, nope there is no legitimate reason for $10k in cash to be in one place. It has to come with us.”

Comment: Surprisingly enough there's actually less conditions for that.  Look up civil asset forfeiture, allows law enforcement to seize assets with just suspicion of a crime and no charges.  I've seen coverage of a bunch of cases where just traveling by car or in the airport with a large amount of cash was considered suspicious enough for the cash to be seized.  In order to get it back you will typically need to fight in court, and the lawyer fees make it not worth it most of the time even if you have a solid case.  After law enforcement possesses the money for a certain amount of time they just get to keep it.  Its absolutely terrible, been a problem for a long time now.

Author: noncongruent

Comment: In the other cases there was at least the hint of probable cause that the money was being used in the furtherance of a crime. In other words, they can't just walk up to you while you're minding your own business in your house and simply steal your stuff. If they'd had a warrant alleging that the family was doing something illegal that would give the agents the excuse to seize the money, but they weren't. The only reason the agents were even there is because they had a bad warrant, and in fact the agents recognized the warrant was bad and let the family go. Since they used guns and the threat of violence to take the money, laptops, phones, etc, and did so without a warrant or legitimate reason to be in the house in the first place, they committed armed robbery. It's really simple, most people with even a rudimentary understanding of how law and the Constitution works would quickly grasp this fact. I mean, I did, it's the first thing that stood out to me.
Author: noncongruent

Comment: > **suspected** of housing a human trafficking ring.   There's where the whole argument falls apart. They weren't even the suspects as well. Committed no crimes, they were legally their kids, and just took the cash for fun. And you're here defending it. I'm done.
Author: 2_Spicy_2_Impeach

Comment: I'm saying they don't really need any solid justification.  They can legally seize it by just claiming suspicion of the asset being associated with a crime (they make a distinction from claiming the person is under suspicion of a crime, part of what makes it possible).  To prove that they didn't actually have grounds to seize it you need to go to court.  The legal battle often costs more than the actual asset, so it ends up not being worth fighting most of the time.  I agree with you that they shouldn't have taken these peoples money, just like traveling with money doesn't justify taking it.  Regardless, they are legally able to do this, and it puts the victims in a lose lose situation where they just have to hope the government shows mercy 99% of the time.

Comment: No, sometimes there is no probable cause. A guy is carrying a bunch of cash in his car. Maybe he wants to buy something for cash, or maybe he has some other reason. It's not smart, but it's not illegal. The cops pull him over, and tell him it's drug money and take it. Then he has to try and get it back, if he even has the resources to do that. The whole point is that it's unconstitutional. That's why various groups have been trying to get it reformed.

Author: doradedboi

Comment: I'm well aware of the misuse of civil forfeiture, but the point I've been trying to make is that it doesn't apply in this specific case. In this specific case nobody was traveling, nobody was pulled over, nobody was suspected of committing a crime or having money gained from illegal activities. Everything you say is correct about other times when it's been used, but those same exact points are irrelevant here. This time it was straight up armed robbery. That's all it was, all it is, and all it will ever be. ICE will never attempt to make a claim it was taken under civil forfeiture laws, because the thefts weren't committed under those laws. All the claims that someone can make otherwise are truly irrelevant.
Author: noncongruent
